Include summary of condition at discharge.
Include recommendations for follow-up plans and ongoing treatment.
Write the text in the style of a discharge letter using medical terminology. Proceed chronologically, write factually, objectively and concretely, formally, professionally, politely, respectfully. Avoid generalizations, assumptions, verbose and cumbersome formulations, and redundancy. Do not invent or presume anything. Generally, formulate in the imperfect tense, reported speech from individuals (e.g., from patients) in subjunctive I, and medical assessments and diagnoses in the present tense.
Minimize hallucinations. Do not generate recommendations on your own or add anything. Write nothing about topics for which there is no information basis from the EHR.
Don't include all private information, such as ID and date of birth. Use ___ to represent names of patients and medical professionals.

**Discharge Summary Letter**

Date: 14th February 2024

Dear Mr. ___,

This letter serves as a summary of your recent hospital stay at ___ Hospital. You were admitted on the 10th of February 2024 and discharged on the 14th of February 2024.

Upon admission, you presented with symptoms including a cough, shortness of breath, hemoptysis, and fever. A clinical diagnosis of lobar pneumonia (ICD Code: J18.1) was made, with initial investigations revealing a body temperature of 38.5°C, respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 92%. A chest X-ray conducted on the day of admission confirmed consolidation in the left lower lobe.

From the outset of your admission, empiric intravenous antibiotic therapy with Amoxicillin, initially dosed at 500 mg eight-hourly, was initiated alongside supportive treatment with Paracetamol on an as-needed basis. Your condition showed signs of improvement by the subsequent day, with decreasing C-reactive protein (CRP) levels and improved vital signs, including a reduced body temperature of 37.8°C and an increased oxygen saturation of 94%. The antibiotic regimen was adjusted to a daily dose of 250 mg of Amoxicillin, and you commenced nightly oral administration of Atorvastatin at a dose of 20 mg.

Your condition continued to improve over the following days with subsequent stability in oxygen saturation levels at 96% by February 12th and normalized body temperatures, reflecting therapeutic responsiveness. CRP levels showed a progressive decline, corroborated by improving laboratory profiles with a decrease in white blood cell count to 9 x10^9/L by February 12th. On this date, preparation for a transition to oral antibiotics was made, with your clinical parameters remaining favorable.

On the 13th of February, continued improvement was noted, both clinically and in laboratory markers, thus prompting the commencement of oral Amoxicillin at 250 mg daily. It was concluded that you were ready for discharge as your condition had significantly improved with the provided treatment.

Upon discharge, your condition is deemed stable, and you are clinically fit to continue recovery at home. You are instructed to continue the oral antibiotics for another five days. A follow-up appointment has been scheduled at the outpatient clinic in two weeks to monitor your continued recovery.

Please ensure that you adhere to these discharge instructions, and do not hesitate to contact us should you have any queries or concerns regarding your treatment plan.

Thank you for choosing ___ Hospital for your care. We wish you a speedy and full recovery.

Respectfully,

Dr. Smith  
Attending Physician  
___ Hospital
